item.description:
Resident Alien (American television series) ðŸ”—

This is a comprehensive overview of the American television series Resident Alien, detailing its genre, creators, cast, production, and reception.

General Information ðŸ”—

This section provides a quick overview of the show, including its genre (comedy-drama, mystery, science fiction), creator (Chris Sheridan), and the comic book it’s based on (by Peter Hogan and Steve Parkhouse). It lists the main actors: Alan Tudyk, Sara Tomko, Corey Reynolds, Alice Wetterlund, Levi Fiehler, Judah Prehn, and Elizabeth Bowen. It also mentions the opening theme song (“Bilgewater” by Brown Bird), the country of origin (United States), the original language (English), the number of seasons (3), and episodes (34). Production details include executive producers, producer (Alan Tudyk), production locations (Delta, British Columbia, Canada), running time (43â€“46 minutes), production companies, original network (Syfy), and release dates (January 27, 2021 â€“ April 3, 2024). It also notes the show’s move to USA Network for a fourth season. A picture depicts the alien language used in the series, which is Esperanto written in an invented script.

Premise ðŸ”—

This section outlines the central plot of the series. An alien crashes on Earth, kills a doctor, and assumes his identity in Patience, Colorado. He is tasked with wiping out humanity but grapples with the morality of his mission, especially after developing compassion and dealing with a child who can see his true form. The alien eventually defends humanity from other extraterrestrial threats.

Cast and Characters ðŸ”—

This section details the main and recurring cast members and their roles.

Main ðŸ”—

  • Alan Tudyk plays the alien, “Harry Vanderspeigle,” who takes on the identity of a doctor. He also plays the real Dr. Harry Vanderspeigle, a corrupt doctor. Keith Arbuthnot portrays the alien in his true form, and David Bianchi portrays Goliath, Harry’s future self.
  • Sara Tomko is Asta Twelvetrees, the doctor’s assistant and a member of the Ute tribe. Brylee Smith and Zara Bacic portray young Asta in flashbacks.
  • Corey Reynolds plays Sheriff Mike Thompson.
  • Alice Wetterlund is D’arcy Bloom, the town bartender and Asta’s best friend. Elle Rivas portrays young D’arcy in flashbacks.
  • Levi Fiehler plays Ben Hawthorne, the town’s mayor. Lukas Goas and Jude Wylie portray young Ben in flashbacks.
  • Judah Prehn is Max Hawthorne, Ben’s son, who can see Harry’s alien form.
  • Elizabeth Bowen plays Deputy Liv Baker. Jessica Halliburton portrays young Liv in flashbacks.

Recurring ðŸ”—

This section lists actors and their recurring roles, including:

  • Meredith Garretson as Kate Hawthorne
  • Ben Cotton as Jimmy
  • Kaylayla Raine as Jay
  • Deborah Finkel as Abigail Hodges
  • Gary Farmer as Dan Twelvetrees
  • Mandell Maughan as Agent Lisa Casper
  • Alex Barima as Lieutenant David Logan
  • Jenna Lamia as Judy Cooper (Lilly Dean portrays young Judy in flashbacks)
  • Sarah Podemski as Kayla (Acahkos Johnson portrays young Kayla in flashbacks)
  • Diana Bang as Ellen Cho
  • Elvy Yost as Isabelle Vanderspeigle
  • Gracelyn Awad Rinke as Sahar
  • Linda Hamilton as General Eleanor McCallister (Alix West Lefler portrays young Eleanor Wright in flashbacks)
  • Michael Cassidy as Dr. Ethan Stone
  • Nathan Fillion as the voice of 42
  • Alvin Sanders as Lewis Thompson
  • Trevor Carroll as John Baker
  • Terry O’Quinn as Peter Bach (Dylan Sloane portrays young Peter Bach in flashbacks)
  • Justin Rain as Elliot
  • Paul Piaskowski as Robert Hutchins
  • Enver Gjokaj as “Joseph Rainier”
  • Nicola Correia-Damude as Detective Lena Torres
  • Kesler Talbot and Andrea Geones as the “Humalien” / “Bridget” (Talbot also portrays the real Bobby Smallwood in flashbacks)
  • Edi Patterson as “Heather”
  • Jewel Staite as Jules Gardner

Guest ðŸ”—

This section lists guest actors and their roles, including:

  • Jan Bos as Dr. Sam Hodges
  • Giorgio A. Tsoukalos as himself
  • David Lewis as Mitch Green
  • Alex Borstein as Carlyn
  • Lini Evans as Bethany Bloom
  • Barclay Hope as Gerald Bloom
  • Taylor Blackwell as Liza Vanderspeigle
  • Maxim Roy as Violinda Darvell
  • Karina Logue as Mary-Ellen Taylor
  • George Takei as the voice of a Grey alien
  • Hwaa Hawk as Leo / Bishop
  • Grace Sunar as Mari
  • Mary Walsh as Patty Baker
  • Erin Karpluk as Dr. Wendy Beasley
  • Clancy Brown as the voice of a Mantid alien
  • Peter Hogan as Mr. Hogan

Episodes ðŸ”—

This section provides an overview of the series’ episodes, broken down by season.

Series overview ðŸ”—

A table summarizes the number of episodes per season, the original release dates, and the network.

Season 1 (2021) ðŸ”—

A table lists each episode of the first season with its title, director, writer, original release date, and U.S. viewership. Brief summaries of each episode’s plot are included.

Season 2 (2022) ðŸ”—

A table lists each episode of the second season with its title, director, writer, original release date, and U.S. viewership. Brief summaries of each episode’s plot are included. The season is divided into two parts.

Season 3 (2024) ðŸ”—

A table lists each episode of the third season with its title, director, writer, original release date, and U.S. viewership. Brief summaries of each episode’s plot are included.

Production ðŸ”—

This section details the development, casting, and filming aspects of the series.

Development ðŸ”—

Series creator Chris Sheridan was inspired by the Resident Alien comic book series and a personal UFO sighting experience. Syfy announced the TV adaptation in 2018, with Universal Cable Productions, Dark Horse Entertainment, and Amblin Television developing the pilot. Syfy gave a series order in 2019, with production in Vancouver and David Dobkin directing the pilot. Robert Duncan McNeill executive produced and directed the remaining episodes. The series was renewed for a second season in 2021 and a third season in 2022. The episode count for the third season was reduced from 12 to 8. In June 2024, the series was renewed for a fourth season and moved to USA Network.

Casting ðŸ”—

Alan Tudyk was cast as the main character, Dr. Harry Vanderspeigle, along with Sara Tomko, Corey Reynolds, Alice Wetterlund, and Levi Fiehler. Linda Hamilton, Mandell Maughan, and Alex Barima were cast in recurring roles, followed by Elizabeth Bowen.

Filming ðŸ”—

Principal photography for the first season began in September 2020 and concluded in October 2020 in Delta, British Columbia, Canada. Filming for the second season began in August 2021 and concluded in April 2022, with locations including Ladysmith, British Columbia. Filming for the third season began in January 2023 and concluded in May 2023. Filming for the fourth season began on December 2, 2024 and concluded on March 31, 2025.

Release ðŸ”—

Syfy announced the series premiere for summer 2020, later moved to January 2021. The series premiered in Canada on CTV Sci-Fi Channel and in the United Kingdom on Sky One.

Reception ðŸ”—

This section summarizes the critical reception and ratings of the series.

Critical response ðŸ”—

The first season received positive reviews, with Rotten Tomatoes reporting a 94% approval rating and Metacritic giving it a score of 70 out of 100. The second season received a 100% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes.

Ratings ðŸ”—

This section provides viewership and ratings data for each episode of the first season, including live viewership, DVR viewership, and total viewership.

Accolades ðŸ”—

A table lists the awards and nominations received by the series, including Saturn Awards, Critics Choice Super Awards, Dragon Awards, Hollywood Critics Association Television Awards, Satellite Awards, Joey Awards, Leo Awards, and Young Artist Awards.

item.title: Alien abduction entities
item.description:
Alien Abduction Entities ðŸ”—

This Wikipedia entry focuses on the beings alleged to be responsible for alien abductions, particularly those involving forced medical examinations with an emphasis on the reproductive system. It highlights the skepticism surrounding the phenomenon within the scientific and mental health communities, attributing such experiences to psychological and environmental factors rather than literal events.

Alleged Motivations ðŸ”—

This section explores the purported reasons behind alien abductions, as claimed by experiencers. Dr. John G. Miller’s research indicates that abductees often report entities claiming a “right” to perform invasive procedures. UFOlogist Jenny Randles’ study of 50 abduction claims reveals that in approximately 60% of cases, abductors provided insights into their motivations, often involving long-term surveillance and interaction. These motivations form a narrative centered on the entities targeting individuals with unique qualities for repeated abductions, during which information is subconsciously implanted for later activation, potentially coinciding with major Earth changes. Different entity types, such as “Nordics” and “Grays,” are said to have varying motivations, with Nordics being perceived as more benevolent.

Types ðŸ”—

This section categorizes the different types of entities reported in alien abduction claims. It presents two tables summarizing these types based on different studies. The first table, based on a survey of 203 pre-1985 abduction claims, lists entities such as Short Humanoids (including short grey aliens), Average Height Humanoids (including tall grey aliens), Tall Humanoids, Mummy-like beings, Miscellaneous Humanoids (including reptoids and hairy dwarves), Human-like beings (including Nordics), and Non-human entities. The second table, based on Claudier Covo’s Brazilian Alien Typology from a study of 138 alleged abductions, categorizes entities as Alpha (0.8â€“1.4 m tall), Beta (1.4â€“2 m tall), Gamma (over 2 m tall), Delta (animals, robots, etc.), Omega (energy beings), and Sigma (very short beings about 0.15 m tall). The section also mentions “Mantid aliens” as frequently reported by abductees, often described as being in charge of the grays.

Reported Technology ðŸ”—

This section details the technological capabilities allegedly displayed by alien abduction entities. Claimants report being levitated, flown around, and witnessing entities passing through walls. Further claimed technical capabilities have been described â€“ including in various books by ufologists â€“ generally without any detailed hypotheses regarding how such appearances or actual capabilities may or may not be possible.

Weapon ðŸ”—

This subsection focuses on a specific weapon allegedly used by grey aliens, as described in Nick Pope’s book The Uninvited. The device is described as a black, cylindrical object, similar in size to a pencil, with a bluish light on one end. It is reportedly used to subdue combative abductees by numbing their will, resembling a Star Trek “phaser” firing a bluish-white beam.

Medical ðŸ”—

This subsection describes a medical device reported by Linda Moulton Howe, based on independent reports from at least two alleged abductions. The device is a pencil-sized cylinder with a light on one end, used in a manner analogous to a surgical scalpel. One abductee described the device opening the chest bloodlessly in “slow motion,” comparing it to a flower blossoming in time-lapse photography, and described the device as “opening the body with sound.”

Plausibility and Veracity ðŸ”—

This section addresses the plausibility and veracity of alien abduction claims, particularly focusing on the influence of hypnosis, geography, culture, and science fiction on abductor descriptions.

Hypnosis as an Influence on Abductor Descriptions ðŸ”—

This subsection examines the impact of hypnosis on the descriptions of abducting beings. Folklorist Thomas E. Bullard notes that the absence of monstrous types in reliable cases contradicts the idea that Hollywood influences abduction reports. He also observes that hypnotically assisted recall tends to produce descriptions of “standard” Grey humanoids, while cases without hypnosis include more variety. Bullard raises the question of whether hypnosis shapes memories or reveals the true appearance of the beings.

Geography and Culture as Influences on Abductor Descriptions ðŸ”—

This subsection explores how geographic and cultural factors influence the details of abduction reports. Robert Sheaffer observes that in North America, large-headed gray aliens are predominant, while in Britain, abduction aliens are usually tall, blond, and Nordic, and South America tends toward more bizarre creatures. The section also notes that common elements in abduction descriptions vary by region and local culture, with only a few elements being consistent worldwide, such as otherworldly sensations, mind control, repressed memories, and sexual experiences, which are also common in stories of encounters with faeries, demons, and other magical creatures. In Brazil, there are strong links between the abduction phenomenon and spiritist traditions, with claims of medical practitioners operating out of a space laboratory.

Science Fiction as an Influence ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses the potential influence of science fiction on abduction reports. Sheaffer notes similarities between aliens depicted in early science fiction films, such as Invaders From Mars, and those reported to have abducted people. Commonalities exist in the appearances, behavior, technology, and societies of fictional and allegedly real abductors. The “abduction narrative” was already established in fictional form by 1930 in a Buck Rogers comic strip. However, Bullard does not see evidence for influence on abduction claimants from science fiction sources.

item.title: Area 51
item.description:
Area 51 ðŸ”—

Area 51, officially called Homey Airport (KXTA) or Groom Lake, is a highly classified United States Air Force (USAF) facility located within the Nevada Test and Training Range. It’s a remote detachment administered by Edwards Air Force Base. While details of its operations are not public, it’s believed to support the development and testing of experimental aircraft and weapons systems. The USAF and CIA acquired the site in 1955, primarily for flight testing the Lockheed U-2 aircraft. The intense secrecy surrounding the base has made it a frequent subject of conspiracy theories and a central component of unidentified flying object (UFO) folklore. The CIA publicly acknowledged the base’s existence in 2013, following a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request. Area 51 is located in southern Nevada, 83 miles (134 km) north-northwest of Las Vegas. The surrounding area, including the town of Rachel, is a popular tourist destination.

Geography ðŸ”—

Area 51 ðŸ”—

The original rectangular base is part of the “Groom box,” a rectangular area of restricted airspace. It’s connected to the Nevada Test Site (NTS) road network, with roads leading to Mercury and Yucca Flat. Groom Lake Road runs northeast through the Jumbled Hills, past a security checkpoint, and descends to the Tikaboo Valley, converging with State Route 375, the “Extraterrestrial Highway,” south of Rachel.

Groom Lake ðŸ”—

Groom Lake is a salt flat in Nevada used for runways of the Nellis Bombing Range Test Site airport (XTA/KXTA) on the north of the Area 51 USAF military installation. The lake is located within the Groom Lake Valley portion of the Tonopah Basin, south of Rachel, Nevada.

History ðŸ”—

The origin of the name “Area 51” is unclear. The correct names for the facility are Homey Airport (XTA/KXTA) and Groom Lake. The facility has also been referred to as “Dreamland” and “Paradise Ranch”. Lead and silver were discovered in the Groom Range in 1864, and the English company Groome Lead Mines Limited financed the Conception Mines in the 1870s. The airfield on the Groom Lake site began service in 1942 as Indian Springs Air Force Auxiliary Field.

U-2 program ðŸ”—

The CIA established the Groom Lake test facility in April 1955 for Project AQUATONE: the development of the Lockheed U-2 strategic reconnaissance aircraft. Project director Richard M. Bissell Jr. understood that the flight test and pilot training programs could not be conducted at Edwards Air Force Base or Lockheed’s Palmdale facility. Lockheed’s U-2 designer Kelly Johnson stated that Groom Lake was ideal due to the dry lake bed and the protection from visitors afforded by the Emigrant Valley’s mountain ranges and the NTS perimeter. The CIA asked the AEC to acquire the land, designated “Area 51” on the map, and to add it to the Nevada Test Site. Johnson named the area “Paradise Ranch” to encourage workers to move to the new facility. The Ranch initially consisted of little more than a few shelters, workshops, and trailer homes. The base received its first U-2 delivery on 24 July 1955.

OXCART program ðŸ”—

Project OXCART was established in August 1959 for work on the Lockheed A-12. This included testing at Groom Lake, which had inadequate facilities. A-12 test facility construction began in September 1960, including a new runway. Reynolds Electrical and Engineering Company (REECo) began construction of “Project 51” on 1 October 1960. The contractor upgraded base facilities and built a new runway diagonally across the southwest corner of the lakebed. They marked an Archimedean spiral on the dry lake approximately two miles (three kilometers) across so that an A-12 pilot approaching the end of the overrun could abort instead of plunging into the sagebrush. Area 51 pilots called it “The Hook”. By August 1961, construction of the essential facilities was complete. Security was enhanced for the arrival of OXCART and the small mine was closed in the Groom basin. In January 1962, the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) expanded the restricted airspace in the vicinity of Groom Lake. The CIA facility received eight USAF F-101 Voodoos for training, two T-33 Shooting Star trainers, a C-130 Hercules for cargo transport, a U-3A for administrative purposes, a helicopter for search and rescue, and a Cessna 180 for liaison use, and Lockheed provided an F-104 Starfighter for use as a chase plane. The first A-12 test aircraft was covertly trucked from Burbank on 26 February 1962 and arrived at Groom Lake on 28 February. It made its first flight 26 April 1962 when the base had over 1,000 personnel. Groom was also the site of the first Lockheed D-21 drone test flight on 22 December 1964. By the end of 1963, nine A-12s were at Area 51, assigned to the CIA-operated “1129th Special Activities Squadron”.

D-21 Tagboard ðŸ”—

Following the loss of Gary Powers’ U-2 over the Soviet Union, there were several discussions about using the A-12 OXCART as an unpiloted drone aircraft. The Air Force agreed to fund the study of a high-speed, high-altitude drone aircraft in October 1962. The project designated “Q-12” was renamed the “D-21”. (The “12” was reversed to “21”). “Tagboard” was the project’s code name. The first D-21 was completed in the spring of 1964 by Lockheed. It was to be carried by a two-seat derivative of the A-12, designated the “M-21”. Difficulties were addressed throughout 1964 and 1965 at Groom Lake with various technical issues. The first D-21 launch was made on 5 March 1966 with a successful flight. An accident on 30 July 1966 with a fully fueled D-21, on a planned checkout flight, suffered from an unstart of the drone after its separation, causing it to collide with the M-21 launch aircraft. Kelly Johnson personally cancelled the entire program. A number of D-21s had already been produced, and rather than scrapping the whole effort, Johnson again proposed to the Air Force that they be launched from a B-52H bomber. The test missions were flown out of Groom Lake, with the actual launches over the Pacific. Several more tests were made, none of which met with success. On 15 July 1971, Kelly Johnson received a wire canceling the D-21B program. The remaining drones were transferred by a C-5A and placed in dead storage. The tooling used to build the D-21Bs was ordered destroyed. In 1993, the B-52/D-21B program was made public. That same year, the surviving D-21Bs were released to museums.

Foreign technology evaluation ðŸ”—

During the Cold War, one of the missions carried out by the United States was the test and evaluation of captured Soviet fighter aircraft. Beginning in the late 1960s, and for several decades, Area 51 played host to an assortment of Soviet-built aircraft. Munir Redfa’s defection with a Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-21 from Iraq for Israel’s Mossad in Operation Diamond led to the HAVE DOUGHNUT, HAVE DRILL and HAVE FERRY programs. The first MiGs flown in the United States were used to evaluate the aircraft in performance, technical, and operational capabilities, pitting the types against U.S. fighters. In August 1966, Iraqi Air Force fighter pilot Captain Munir Redfa defected, flying his MiG-21 to Israel after being ordered to attack Iraqi Kurd villages with napalm. His aircraft was transferred to Groom Lake in late 1967 for study. Israel loaned the MiG-21 to the US Air Force from January 1968 to April 1968. In 1968, the US Air Force and Navy jointly formed a project known as HAVE DOUGHNUT in which Air Force Systems Command, Tactical Air Command, and the U.S. Navy’s Air Test and Evaluation Squadron Four (VX-4) flew this acquired Soviet-made aircraft in simulated air combat training. On 12 August 1968, two Syrian air force lieutenants, Walid Adham and Radfan Rifai, took off in a pair of MiG-17Fs on a training mission. They lost their way and, believing they were over Lebanon, landed at the Betzet Landing Field in northern Israel. Prior to the end of 1968 these MiG-17s were transferred from Israeli stocks and added to the Area 51 test fleet. The data from the HAVE DOUGHNUT and HAVE DRILL tests were provided to the newly formed Top Gun school at NAS Miramar

item.title: Alien abduction
item.description:
Alien Abduction ðŸ”—

Alien abduction, also known as abduction phenomenon, alien abduction syndrome, or UFO abduction, is the subjective experience of individuals reporting being kidnapped by extraterrestrial beings and subjected to physical and psychological experimentation. Those who claim to have been abducted are referred to as “abductees” or “experiencers.” The prevailing scientific and mental health perspective attributes these experiences to factors like suggestibility, sleep paralysis, deception, and psychopathology. Skeptics note similarities between alien descriptions and those in science fiction films.

Overview ðŸ”—

Mainstream scientists generally dismiss claims of literal alien abduction. However, some researchers, like psychiatrist John E. Mack, argue that many abductees are sane individuals. A subculture has developed around the phenomenon, complete with support groups and a detailed mythos involving various alien types (Greys, Reptilians, Nordics) with specific roles and motivations. Some abductees explain the lack of wider awareness as a result of extraterrestrial or governmental cover-ups.

History ðŸ”—

Paleo-abductions ðŸ”—

This section discusses older stories that some UFO researchers, like Jerome Clark, have interpreted as possible early cases of alien abduction, termed “paleo-abductions.” Examples include:

  • A November 27, 1896, report in The Evening Mail of Stockton, California, where Colonel H. G. Shaw claimed he and a friend were harassed by tall, slender humanoids who tried to kidnap them.
  • A 1953 Man to Man Magazine article by Leroy Thorpe, questioning if humans were being captured by flying saucers for experimentation.
  • Harold T. Wilkins’s 1955 publication Flying Saucers Uncensored, which reported the mysterious disappearance of Karl Hunrath and Wilbur Wilkinson, who had claimed contact with aliens, suggesting they might have been abducted.

Two Landmark Cases ðŸ”—

This section highlights two early alien abduction claims that gained significant attention:

  • The AntÃ´nio Vilas-Boas case in Brazil in the mid-1950s.
  • The Betty and Barney Hill abduction in 1961, which received widespread publicity and was dramatized in a 1975 television film. The Hill incident is considered a prototypical abduction case, introducing the beings later known as the Greys and explicitly identifying an extraterrestrial origin.

Skeptic Peter Rogerson notes that these cases established a template for later abduction reports.

Later Developments ðŸ”—

This section discusses the evolution of the alien abduction phenomenon and the involvement of key figures:

  • R. Leo Sprinkle, a University of Wyoming psychologist, became interested in abductions in the 1960s and linked them to cattle mutilation.
  • Budd Hopkins, an artist interested in UFOs, began using hypnosis in the 1970s to uncover details of abduction experiences, becoming a figurehead in the abductee subculture.
  • The 1980s saw increased mainstream attention, with works by Hopkins, Whitley Strieber, David M. Jacobs, and John E. Mack presenting alien abduction as a plausible experience.
  • Thomas E. Bullard’s comparative analysis of nearly 300 alleged abductees was also published in the 1980s.
  • Jacobs and Hopkins argued that alien abduction was far more common than previously suspected and that aliens were attempting to create human-alien hybrids.

According to Linda Rodriguez McRobbie of the Boston Globe, abduction stories have declined in mainstream media in recent decades. Michael Shermer suggests that camera phones have increased the burden of evidence for such claims.

John E. Mack ðŸ”—

This section focuses on Harvard psychiatry professor John E. Mack, who believed in the credibility of alien abduction claims. Niall Boyce, writing in The Lancet, criticized Mack for uncritically elaborating on abduction tales and potentially creating false memories. Mack interviewed over 800 people and wrote two books on the subject, but his professional reputation suffered as a result.

Abductees ðŸ”—

This section discusses the demographics and mental health of alleged abductees. The precise number of abductees is uncertain, with estimates ranging from 1,700 claimants in early studies to 5â€“6 percent of the general population in contested surveys.

Demographics ðŸ”—

Reports are usually made by adults, but sometimes young children report similar experiences. These child-reports often feature very specific details in common with reports of abduction made by adults, including the circumstances, narrative, entities and aftermaths of the alleged occurrences. Often, these young abductees have family members who have reported having abduction experiences. Family involvement in the military, or a residence near a military base is also common among child abduction claimants.

Mental Health ðŸ”—

Some studies suggest that abductees have psychological characteristics that render their testimony suspect, while others show that “as a group, abduction experients are not different from the general population in term of psychopathology prevalence”. Elizabeth Slater conducted a blind study of nine abduction claimants and found them to be prone to “mildly paranoid thinking”, nightmares and having a weak sexual identity, while Richard McNally of Harvard Medical School concluded in a similar study of 10 abductees that “none of them was suffering from any sort of psychiatric illness.”

Political Conspiracy Theories ðŸ”—

This section explores the connections between radical politics and conspiracy theories involving UFOs, alien visitation, and government cover-ups. Political scientist Michael Barkun highlights the rise of “improvisional millenarism” and the role of UFO and abduction stories in stigmatized knowledge narratives. He notes the emergence of alien-related conspiracy theories in far-right politics from the 1980s onwards. TV shows like The X-Files are mentioned as examples of popular culture incorporating alien conspiracies. Jodi Dean notes that the stigma of alien abduction stories is seductive to dismiss “consensus reality” in favor of deviant alternative realities. Self-described abduction victims may join self-help communities and espouse conspiracy theories involving mind control and a New World Order.

Abduction Narrative ðŸ”—

This section outlines the common elements and sequence of events reported in abduction narratives. According to CUFOS’s definition of abductee, the person must have been taken against their will by apparent non-human beings, taken to a special place perceived as extraterrestrial or to be a spaceship. They then must experience being subjected to an examination or to engage in some form of communication with the beings (or both). Communication may be perceived as telepathic rather than verbal. The memory of the experience may be conscious or “recovered” through means like hypnosis.

Thomas E. Bullard argues that there is a broad, fairly consistent sequence and description of events that make up the typical “close encounter of the fourth kind.” These events include:

  1. Capture: The abductee is rendered incapable of resisting and taken to an alien spacecraft.
  2. Examination and Procedures: Invasive physiological and psychological procedures.
  3. Conference: Communication with the abductors, typically telepathically.
  4. Tour: A tour of the captors’ vessel.
  5. Loss of Time: Rapid forgetting of the experience.
  6. Return: Return to Earth, sometimes in a different location.
  7. Theophany: A profound sense of love or a mystical experience.
  8. Aftermath: Coping with the psychological, physical, and social effects of the experience.

David M. Jacobs emphasizes the orchestrated nature of the abduction event.

Capture ðŸ”—

Abduction claimants report unusual feelings preceding the onset of an abduction experience. These feelings manifest as a compulsive desire to be at a certain place at a certain time or as expectations that something “familiar yet unknown” will soon occur. Abductees also report feeling severe, undirected anxiety at this point even though nothing unusual has actually occurred yet. Eventually, the experiencer will undergo an apparent “shift” into an altered state of consciousness. As consciousness shifts one or more lights are alleged to appear, occasionally accompanied by a strange mist. As the alleged abduction proceeds, claimants say they will walk or be levitated into an alien craft, in the latter case often through solid objects such as walls, ceilings or a closed window.

Examination ðŸ”—

The examination phase is characterized by medical procedures and examinations performed by alien beings against the will of the experiencer. These procedures often focus on sex and reproductive biology. John G. Miller notes differences between human medicine and what is reported as being practiced by the abductors.

Subsequent Procedures ðŸ”—

After the medical exam, abductees often report other procedures, including imaging, envisioning, staging, and testing.

  • “Imaging” involves viewing screens displaying emotionally provocative images.
  • “Envisioning” involves images projected into the experiencer’s mind.
  • “Staging” involves the abductee interacting with an illusionary scenario.
  • “Testing” involves operating a complicated electronic device.

Child Presentation ðŸ”—

Abductees sometimes report being shown a “child” who appears to be a hybrid between humans and their abductors. Thomas E. Bullard could not identify a child presentation phase in the abduction narrative, even after undertaking a study of 300 abduction reports.

Less Common Elements ðŸ”—

Bullard’s study of 300 abduction reports also identified less prominent aspects of the claims, including:

  1. The conference
  2. The tour
  3. The journey
  4. Theophany

These episodes tend to happen between the medical examination and the return.

Return ðŸ”—

item.title: Alien Autopsy (1995 television film)
item.description:
Alien Autopsy (1995 television film) ðŸ”—

This article discusses the 1995 pseudo-documentary Alien Autopsy: Fact or Fiction, which featured footage purporting to show an alien autopsy conducted after the Roswell incident. The article distinguishes the original footage from the 2006 feature film Alien Autopsy, which is based on the events surrounding the creation of the hoax.

Production ðŸ”—

This section details the production of the Alien Autopsy footage. It highlights Ray Santilli and Gary Shoefield’s admission in the 2006 documentary Eamonn Investigates: Alien Autopsy that they created the 1995 footage. The section describes how they filmed a simulated autopsy on a fabricated alien in a set constructed in a London living room. Artist and sculptor John Humphreys constructed two dummy alien bodies filled with raspberry jam, sheep brains, chicken entrails, and knuckle joints. Humphreys also played the role of the chief examiner. The section also mentions the creation of alien artifacts and the recruitment of a homeless man to play the role of the cameraman.

In popular culture ðŸ”—

This section explores how Alien Autopsy was received and satirized in the media. It mentions The X-Files referencing the footage and later satirizing it in the episode “Jose Chung’s From Outer Space”. It also notes Fox airing a special debunking the footage and the release of the comedy film Alien Autopsy (2006), which fictionalized the creation of the footage.

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including books, news articles, and documentaries.

Further reading ðŸ”—

item.title: Cattle mutilation
item.description:
Cattle Mutilation ðŸ”—

Cattle mutilation refers to the killing and mutilation of cattle (and other animals) under unusual and anomalous circumstances, often described as bloodless. The phenomenon is frequently linked to paranormal or supernatural explanations, including cults, government agencies, cryptids like the chupacabra, and extraterrestrials. The article notes that it has been the subject of two independent federal investigations in the United States.

Early History ðŸ”—

The earliest documented cases of unexplained livestock deaths occurred in England in 1606. Charles Fort collected accounts of cattle mutilations in England during the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

The “Snippy” Horse Death of 1967 ðŸ”—

The unexplained death and mutilation of a horse named “Snippy” in Alamosa, Colorado, in 1967 brought the phenomenon to wider attention. The case involved precise cuts, a lack of blood, and a medicinal odor. This incident was the first to link mutilations to extraterrestrials and UFOs. Wadsworth Ayer’s investigation for the Condon Committee concluded there was no evidence of abnormal causes. Alamosa County Sheriff Ben Phillips suggested a lightning strike, but later reports mentioned the horse had been shot. Two students confessed to shooting the horse after the case gained publicity.

Cattle Mutilations 1973â€“1980 ðŸ”—

This period saw waves of cattle mutilations reported in Kansas, Nebraska, Colorado, and New Mexico. In April 1973, sheriffs in Western Iowa reported unidentified helicopters involved in cattle and pig rustling. Similar rustling was reported in Missouri in August.

1973 Kansas Wave ðŸ”—

In June 1973, Cloud County sheriff Fred Modlin warned the public about suspicious phone calls from someone posing as a USDA official. A series of butchered cows were found on farms in Cloud County, with right ears removed. Local press speculated about a “Mad Dog” or “phantom” Butcher. By December, law enforcement reported a wave of cattle deaths in seven counties across Kansas and Nebraska, with sexual organs removed. State Senator Ross Doyen reported a cattle mutilation on his ranch. The Kansas Brand Commissioner’s office attributed most deaths to natural causes, but Modlin and others disagreed.

1974 Nebraska Wave ðŸ”—

Reports resumed in April 1974, with a Nebraska cow found mutilated and drained of blood. The North American Newspaper Alliance reported on the 1973 mutilations and unidentified helicopter sightings. Mutilations were reported in Mills County, Iowa, and Lancaster County, Nebraska. Custer County reported helicopter sightings and armed patrols. In August, an unidentified helicopter was spotted hovering above a field where a mutilated cow was later found near Agnew, Nebraska. Knox County Sheriff Herbert Thompson reported armed civilian patrols. Cloud County Attorney William Walsh mentioned a jailhouse informant who claimed the mutilations were the result of devil-worshiping cultists. State Sen. John Decamp called for a coordinated investigation. A rancher near Hartington apparently thwarted a mutilation in progress when he found a helicopter above his field. Authorities cautioned the public not to shoot at aircraft. The University of Nebraska’s Department of Veterinary Science disproved three mutilations, attributing them to natural causes. Law enforcement officials from 24 counties attended a meeting in Center, Nebraska, to discuss the mutilations. Three cases of alleged mutilations were reported in South Dakota. Newsweek became the first national outlet to cover the story, reporting 100 cattle mutilated in Nebraska, Kansas, and Iowa since May. South Dakota Attorney General Kermit Sande reported mutilations in the state. UFO expert J. Allen Hynek denied any link between UFOs and mutilations. Two mutilations were reported in Kandiyohi County, six in Swift County, and one in Meeker County, Minnesota.

1975 Colorado ðŸ”—

In 1975, the Colorado Associated Press voted the mutilations as the state’s top story. Senator Floyd K. Haskell contacted the FBI for help due to public concern, claiming 130 mutilations in Colorado and reports across nine states. A 1979 FBI report indicated an estimated 8,000 mutilations in Colorado, causing approximately $1 million in damages. Donald E. Flickinger of the Michigan ATF investigated possible links to a “Hell-oriented biker gang.” The Colorado Bureau of Investigation opened an investigation under Carl Whiteside. The New York Times published a story examining cattle mutilations across 11 states.

1976 Dulce, New Mexico ðŸ”—

On June 13, 1976, Dulce rancher Manuel Gomez reported a mutilation to Officer Gabe Valdez of the New Mexico State Patrol.

1979 Public Meeting ðŸ”—

On April 20, 1979, U.S. Attorney R. E. Thompson and US Senator Harrison Schmidt held a public meeting about cattle mutilations. Paul Bennewitz reported seeing unidentified lights over Kirtland Air Force Base. On May 2, 1979, Valdez reported that two drugs had been found in the remains of a mutilated bull, one to tranquilize the animal and another to remove blood. On June 14, 1981, investigators found a mutilated cow at the Gomez ranch with radar chaff nearby.

Later Incidents ðŸ”—

Many cases of mutilation have been reported worldwide since 1967, chiefly in the Americas and Australia. In South America, an estimated 3,500 incidents have occurred since 2002.

In 1993, photographic evidence surfaced of a mutilated male human corpse found near the Guarapiranga reservoir of SÃ£o Paulo, Brazil, in 1988.

Characteristics ðŸ”—

Unusual cattle deaths are characterized by the absence of sex organs, udders, tongues, anus, rectum, and sometimes ears or eyes. Cuts are described as “clean” and “surgical.” Some animals are reported to have been drained of blood with no sign of blood in the immediate area. Howard Burgess stated that nearly 90 percent of mutilated cattle are between four and five years old. Strange marks or imprints near the site have been found.

Laboratory Reports ðŸ”—

Laboratory reports on some mutilated animals have shown unusual levels of vitamins or minerals in tissue samples and the presence of chemicals not normally found in animals. In one case in Dulce, New Mexico, a bull was found mutilated with the rectum and sex organs removed. The animal’s heart and liver were found to be inconsistent with a normal case of death followed by predation. The liver was found to be completely devoid of copper and to contain 4 times the normal level of zinc, potassium, and phosphorus. Blood samples were reported to be “light pink in color” and “Did not clot after several days.”

Helicopter Sightings ðŸ”—

On July 15, 1974, two unregistered helicopters were reported to have opened fire on Robert Smith Jr. in Honey Creek, Iowa. On August 20, 1974, the Lincoln Journal Star reported that residents had seen unidentified helicopters shining spotlights into fields where mutilated cows were later found. By 1975, some ranchers formed armed vigilante groups. In 1976, two Cache County, Utah, police officers reportedly confronted several men in an unmarked U.S. Army helicopter. On April 8, 1979, three police officers in Dulce, New Mexico, reported a mysterious aircraft resembling a U.S. military helicopter hovering around a site following a wave of alleged mutilation.

Official Investigations ðŸ”—

The New Mexico Livestock Board sought assistance from the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory. Colorado Bureau of Investigation agents went undercover to investigate. Oklahoma convened a task force. Federal authorities launched a comprehensive investigation.

Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms ðŸ”—

In January 1975, the Minnesota field office of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms (ATF) launched an investigation, headed by Agent Donald Flickinger, into possible connections between cults and cattle mutilation. Flickinger recorded unusual incidents and circumstantial evidence but was unable to find sufficient evidence of cult involvement.

Colorado Bureau of Investigation ðŸ”—

In May 1975, the Colorado Bureau of Investigation opened an investigation under the leadership of Carl Whiteside. 19 animals underwent necropsies at Colorado State University but no conclusive results emerged. The US Bureau of Land Management was forced to ground all helicopters in Eastern Colorado. By December, the CBI had investigated 203 reports of cattle mutilations.

New Mexico State Police ðŸ”—

On June 13, 1976, the New Mexico State Police began an investigation, headed by Officer Gabe Valdez, with the assistance of Cattle Inspector Jim Dyad and Officer Howard Johnston of the New Mexico Department of Game and Fish. On the night of July 5, Burgess and Valdez screened the Gomez herd; five animals were found to have been marked with a chemical that fluoresced under ultraviolet light. On June 14, 1981, intact radar chaff was found near a mutilated cow on the Gomez ranch. This investigation reported finding evidence that some mutilated animals had been tranquilized and treated with an anti-coagulant prior to their mutilation.

Rommel Investigation ðŸ”—

Beginning in May 1979, an investigation was funded by a grant from the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration and was headed by recently-retired FBI agent Kenneth Rommel. Rommel’s final report, released in June 1980, concluded that the mutilations were predominantly the result of natural

item.title: UFO conspiracy theories
item.description:
UFO Conspiracy Theories ðŸ”—

This Wikipedia entry delves into the world of UFO conspiracy theories, exploring the belief that governments, particularly the United States government, are suppressing evidence of extraterrestrial life and technology. It examines the historical development of these theories, their proponents, and their presence in popular culture and religion.

Overview ðŸ”—

This section introduces the core concept of UFO conspiracy theories: the alleged suppression of evidence regarding extraterrestrial-controlled UFOs or technology. It notes the evolution of these theories, from initial claims of government cover-ups to more complex narratives involving communication and cooperation with extraterrestrials, including claims of government allowance of cattle mutilation and alien abduction. It also mentions the Committee for Skeptical Inquiry’s stance that there is little to no evidence supporting these theories.

Mainstream Views ðŸ”—

This section presents the mainstream scientific perspective on UFOs. It acknowledges the historical and cultural prominence of UFO sightings, particularly after World War II and during the Space Age. It highlights government and independent investigations that have failed to confirm extraordinary claims made by ufologists. Prosaic explanations for UFO sightings, such as natural phenomena, human technology, delusions, and hoaxes, are offered. The section also touches upon the psychosocial explanations for UFO beliefs and their influence on new religions. Benjamin Radford’s argument about the unlikelihood of a decades-long, international cover-up is also presented.

Notable Proponents ðŸ”—

This section identifies key figures associated with UFO conspiracy theories. Donald Keyhoe, Jacque Vallee, J. Allen Hynek, and Stanton Friedman are mentioned as prominent voices from the 1950s to the 1970s. It also notes that some early proponents, like Richard Shaver and Paul Bennewitz, suffered from psychiatric issues, and that some proponents confessed to hoaxes or lies. The section lists individuals in positions of authority, such as Senator Barry Goldwater, Admiral Lord Hill-Norton, Vice Admiral Roscoe H. Hillenkoetter, and astronauts Gordon Cooper and Edgar Mitchell, who have suggested that UFO evidence is being suppressed. 21st-century proponents like Paul Hellyer, Garry Nolan, Haim Eshed, Jim Semivan, Harold E. Puthoff, Tom DeLonge, Luis Elizondo, and David Grusch are also mentioned.

In Popular Fiction ðŸ”—

This section explores the portrayal of government cover-ups of extraterrestrial contact in popular fiction. Films like 2001: A Space Odyssey, Easy Rider, Close Encounters of the Third Kind, E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial, Flight of the Navigator, Total Recall, Independence Day, and Men in Black are cited as examples. Television series such as The X-Files, Dark Skies, and Stargate are also mentioned. The section also notes John Glenn’s appearance on Frasier, Sidney Sheldon’s novel The Doomsday Conspiracy, and the series American Horror Story: Double Feature.

In Religion ðŸ”—

This section examines the intersection of UFO conspiracy theories and religion. It identifies new religious movements, including the Nation of Islam, Scientology, and Heaven’s Gate, that have incorporated UFO-related beliefs. Mormon cosmology, Theosophy, and the “I AM” Activity are also discussed. The section mentions the Nation of Islam’s concept of “The Mother Plane,” the UFO religions Unarius and the Aetherius Society, L. Ron Hubbard’s teachings about Xenu in Scientology, and the RaÃ«lism movement. It concludes with the Heaven’s Gate mass suicide and the Order of the Solar Temple mass deaths.

Chronology of UFO Conspiracy Theories ðŸ”—

This section provides a detailed timeline of the development of UFO conspiracy theories, starting with Raymond Palmer’s pulp magazine Amazing Stories in the 1940s.

1940s Origin in Raymond Palmer’s Pulp Magazine ðŸ”—

This subsection focuses on Raymond Palmer, the editor of Amazing Stories, and his role in popularizing UFO conspiracy theories. It mentions his publication of Richard Shaver’s stories about a secret underground race and Palmer’s claim that world governments were aware of spaceships visiting Earth.

Spaceships of “The Shaver Mystery” ðŸ”—

This subsection details Richard Shaver’s claims of telepathic communication with a secret underground race and their mastery of space travel. It notes Shaver’s history of psychiatric problems and the blurring of fact and fiction in his stories.

Kenneth Arnold Ignites Flying Disc Craze ðŸ”—

This subsection covers the beginning of the flying disc craze with Kenneth Arnold’s sighting in 1947. It mentions the Roswell incident and the Army’s initial press release about recovering a “flying disc.” It also discusses Palmer’s investigation of Fred Crisman’s claims near Maury Island, Washington, and the subsequent plane crash.

Aftermath ðŸ”—

This subsection describes the aftermath of the Maury Island incident and the continued promotion of UFO conspiracy theories by Palmer and Shaver. It mentions Shaver’s “rock books” and Palmer’s later admission that Shaver had spent time in a mental institution. It also notes Palmer’s claim of a link between flying saucers, the Shaver Mystery, the Kennedy assassination, Watergate, and Fred Crisman.

National Coverage in the 1950s ðŸ”—

This section discusses the increase in governmental and civilian investigative efforts and reports of public disinformation and suppression of evidence in the 1950s.

The Flying Saucer Conspiracy ðŸ”—

This subsection focuses on Donald Keyhoe’s role in promoting UFO conspiracy theories in the 1950s. It mentions his article “The Flying Saucers Are Real” and his book The Flying Saucer Conspiracy, which accused the government of covering up knowledge of flying saucers. It also describes Keyhoe’s appearance on CBS’s Armstrong Circle Theatre and the cutting of his microphone during the live broadcast.

Aztec “Alien Bodies” Hoax ðŸ”—

This subsection details the Frank Scully’s “alien bodies” conspiracy theory, which claimed that dead extraterrestrial beings were recovered from a flying saucer crash. It mentions Scully’s book Behind the Flying Saucers and the later exposure of Scully as a victim of confidence artists.

Air Force Accounts ðŸ”—

This subsection covers the Air Force’s response to UFO sightings in the 1950s. It mentions General John Samford’s press conference on the Washington D.C. UFO incident, the Robertson Panel’s recommendation for public education, and Al Chop’s role as the press spokesman for Project Bluebook. It also discusses Captain Edward J. Ruppelt’s book The Report on Unidentified Flying Objects.

“Philadelphia Experiment” Hoax ðŸ”—

This subsection describes the “Philadelphia Experiment” hoax, which involved claims of a navy ship being made invisible and teleporting. It mentions Morris K. Jessup’s book The Case for the UFO and the letters he received from “Carlos Miguel Allende” (Carl Meredith Allen). It also discusses the annotated copy of Jessup’s book and Jessup’s death by suicide.

‘Men in Black’ Legends ðŸ”—

This subsection explores the legend of the Men in Black, popularized by Gray Barker’s book They Knew Too Much About Flying Saucers. It mentions the speculation that the men in black are government agents who harass and threaten UFO witnesses.

1960-70s: Growing Distrust in Government ðŸ”—

This section discusses the growing government skepticism in the 1960s and 1970s, fueled by events like the Kennedy assassination, the Pentagon Papers, and the Watergate scandal.

Michigan “Swamp Gas” UFO Reports ðŸ”—

This subsection covers the 1966 UFO reports in Michigan and the Air Force’s explanation that they were caused by swamp gas. It notes the ridicule that followed and the call for a Congressional investigation.

Fred Crisman and JFK Conspiracy Theories ðŸ”—

This subsection details Fred Crisman’s involvement in the JFK assassination conspiracy theories. It mentions Jim Garrison’s prosecution of Clay Shaw and Crisman’s testimony before the New Orleans grand jury.

“Cosmic Watergate” ðŸ”—

This subsection explores the concept of a “Cosmic Watergate,” referring to a government cover-up of UFO information. It mentions the film 2001: A Space Odyssey and J. Allen Hynek’s claim that Bluebook was a “Cosmic Watergate.”

Alien Bodies at “Hangar 18” ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses the legends of alien bodies being stored at “Hangar 18” at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base. It mentions Robert Spencer Carr’s claim that alien bodies recovered from the Aztec crash were stored there.

“Alien Abductions” ðŸ”—

This subsection covers the rise of alien abduction claims in the 1970s. It mentions the Betty and Barney Hill case, the Travis Walton incident, and the work of Budd Hopkins and Whitley Strieber.

Close Encounters of the Third Kind ðŸ”—

This subsection explores the influence of the film Close Encounters of the Third Kind on UFO conspiracy theories. It mentions the film’s depiction of a government cover-up and the involvement of J. Allen Hynek and Jacques Vallee.

Jesse Marcel and Roswell ðŸ”—

This subsection details Jesse Marcel’s role in the Roswell incident and his later statements suggesting that the debris might have been extraterrestrial. It mentions the National Enquirer’s coverage of the story and the US military’s later reports disclosing the true nature of the crashed aircraft.

item.title: Grey alien
item.description:
Grey Aliens ðŸ”—

Grey aliens, also known as Zeta Reticulans, Roswell Greys, or simply Greys, are alleged extraterrestrial beings frequently featured in close encounter and alien abduction claims. They are typically depicted as small humanoids with grey skin, large heads, and black, almond-shaped eyes. The Barney and Betty Hill abduction case in 1961 is credited with popularizing the Grey alien image. These beings have become an archetypal representation of intelligent non-human creatures and extraterrestrial life in popular culture.

Description ðŸ”—

This section details the typical physical characteristics attributed to Grey aliens. They are generally described as diminutive humanoid beings with grey skin and reduced or absent external human features like noses, ears, or sex organs. Their bodies are elongated with small chests, lacking muscular definition and visible skeletal structure. They have disproportionately large heads, no hair, and small openings for ears, nostrils, and mouths. Their most striking feature is their large, opaque, black eyes.

Appearance ðŸ”—

This subsection elaborates on the physical appearance of Greys. They are typically depicted as grey-skinned, small humanoids with reduced or absent external human body parts. Their bodies are elongated, with small chests, lacking muscular definition and visible skeletal structure. Their legs are shorter and jointed differently from humans. They have unusually large heads in proportion to their bodies, no hair, and no noticeable outer ears or noses. They are almost always shown with very large, opaque, black eyes, without eye whites, and are frequently described as shorter than average adult humans.

Association with Zeta Reticuli ðŸ”—

This subsection explains the connection between Grey aliens and the Zeta Reticuli star system. The association originated with Marjorie Fish’s interpretation of a map drawn by Betty Hill in 1969. Hill, under hypnosis, claimed to have been shown a map displaying the aliens’ home system and nearby stars. Fish created a model from Hill’s drawing and determined that the stars marked as the aliens’ home were Zeta Reticuli, a binary star system.

History ðŸ”—

This section traces the origins and evolution of the Grey alien archetype. Descriptions of beings similar to Greys predate claims of encounters with them. H.G. Wells described humans with similar features in his writings from the late 19th century. Aleister Crowley described a meeting with a similar entity named Lam as early as 1917. Gustav Sandgren, writing as Gabriel Linde, described similar aliens in his 1933 science fiction novel The Unknown Danger.

Origins ðŸ”—

This subsection details the literary and occult origins of the Grey alien archetype. In 1893, H.G. Wells described humanity’s future appearance as lacking mouths, noses, or hair, and with large heads. In 1895, Wells depicted the Eloi in similar terms in The Time Machine. As early as 1917, Aleister Crowley described a meeting with a “preternatural entity” named Lam, similar in appearance to a modern Grey. In 1933, Gustav Sandgren, writing as Gabriel Linde, published The Unknown Danger, describing extraterrestrials with grey fabric clothes, short stature, big bald heads, and large, dark, gleaming eyes.

Barney and Betty Hill abduction ðŸ”—

This subsection focuses on the Barney and Betty Hill abduction case and its role in popularizing the Grey alien archetype. Newspaper reports of the Betty and Barney Hill abduction in 1965 made the archetype famous. The Hills claimed that in 1961, grey-skinned humanoid alien beings abducted them and took them to a flying saucer. Martin Kottmeyer suggested that Barney’s memories might have been influenced by an episode of The Outer Limits titled “The Bellero Shield.” Carl Sagan echoed Kottmeyer’s suspicions, citing Invaders from Mars as another potential inspiration.

Diffusion into folklore ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses how Greys became an integral part of ufology and extraterrestrial-related folklore after the Hills’ encounter. According to journalist C.D.B. Bryan, 73% of all reported alien encounters in the United States describe Grey aliens. In the early 1980s, Greys were linked to the alleged crash-landing of a flying saucer in Roswell, New Mexico, in 1947. In 1987, Whitley Strieber published the book Communion, describing his alleged close encounters with Greys and other extraterrestrial beings. In 1988, Jimmy Guieu described “the little greys” on French television. In 1995, Ray Santilli claimed to have obtained film footage depicting the autopsy of a “real” Grey recovered from the Roswell incident.

Analysis ðŸ”—

This section explores various analyses and interpretations of the Grey alien phenomenon.

In close encounter claims and ufology ðŸ”—

This subsection examines the role of Greys in alien abduction claims and ufology. Greys are often involved in alien abduction claims, making up about 50% of reports in Australia, 73% in the United States, 48% in continental Europe, and around 12% in the United Kingdom. These reports include two distinct groups of Greys that differ in height. Abduction claims are often described as extremely traumatic. The eyes are often a focus of abduction claims, with Greys staring into the eyes of abductees when conducting mental procedures.

Psychocultural expression of intelligence ðŸ”—

This subsection presents neurologist Steven Novella’s theory that Grey aliens are a byproduct of the human imagination, with their distinctive features representing everything that modern humans traditionally link with intelligence.

The “Mother Hypothesis” ðŸ”—

This subsection introduces Frederick V. Malmstrom’s idea that Greys are actually residual memories of early childhood development. Malmstrom reconstructs the face of a Grey through transformation of a mother’s face based on our best understanding of early-childhood sensation and perception.

Evolutionary implausibility ðŸ”—

This subsection presents biologist Jack Cohen’s argument that the typical image of a Grey is too physiologically similar to a human to be credible as a representation of an alien from a world with different environmental and ecological conditions.

Other hypotheses ðŸ”—

This subsection mentions alternative explanations for the humanoid anatomy and behavior of alleged Grey aliens, including the interdimensional hypothesis, the cryptoterrestrial hypothesis, and the time-traveler hypothesis.

In popular culture ðŸ”—

This section discusses the prevalence of Grey aliens in popular culture. Depictions of Grey aliens have appeared in numerous films and television shows, supplanting the previously popular little green men. Examples include Ultraman, Close Encounters of the Third Kind, Babylon 5, Stargate, and South Park. During the 1990s, plotlines wherein Greys were linked to conspiracy theories became common, such as in The X-Files. Other examples include the XCOM video game franchise, Dark Skies, and American Dad!. The 2011 film Paul tells the story of a Grey named Paul who attributes the Greys’ frequent presence in science fiction pop culture to the US government deliberately inserting the stereotypical Grey alien image into mainstream media. Child abduction by Greys is a key plot point in the 2013 film, Dark Skies. Greys appear in Syfy’s 2021 science fiction dramedy series Resident Alien. The Greys appear as the main antagonistic faction in the 2023 independent game Greyhill Incident.

item.title: Nordic aliens
item.description:
Nordic Aliens ðŸ”—

In ufology, “Nordics,” “Nordic aliens,” or “Tall Whites” are terms used to describe alleged humanoid extraterrestrial races from the Pleiades star cluster. These beings are said to resemble Nordic, Germanic, or Scandinavian humans, with features like tall stature (6-7 ft), blond hair, blue eyes, and fair skin. Some reports describe their skin tone as pale blue/grey or pastel purple.

History ðŸ”—

Cultural historian David J. Skal suggests that early stories of Nordic aliens may have been inspired by the 1951 film The Day the Earth Stood Still. Stephanie Kelley-Romano describes alien abduction beliefs as a “living myth,” noting that believers often associate Nordic aliens with spiritual growth and protection.

In ufology, Nordic aliens are often portrayed as benevolent beings concerned about Earth’s ecology and world peace, possessing telepathic powers and described as paternal, watchful, smiling, affectionate, and youthful.

During the 1950s, many people, especially in Europe, claimed encounters with these beings. However, such claims became less common in later decades as the grey alien became more prevalent in extraterrestrial encounter accounts.

Publications by Those Claiming to Have Been Contacted ðŸ”—

Several books detail alleged personal contact with Nordic aliens, including:

  • Flying Saucers Have Landed by Desmond Leslie and George Adamski
  • Inside the Space Ships by George Adamski
  • From Outer Space to You by Howard Menger
  • The Walton Experience by Travis Walton
  • Millennial Hospitality by Charles James Hall (adapted into the film Walking with the Tall Whites)

The UFO religion Universe People also publishes interactions with “Cosmic Friends.”

item.title: Alien Hive
item.description:
Alien Hive ðŸ”—

Alien Hive is a puzzle video game developed and published by Malaysia-based studio Appxplore in March 2013. It is available on iOS, Android, and Windows Phone platforms. The game blends match-three mechanics with sliding puzzle elements.

Gameplay ðŸ”—

The core gameplay involves swiping tiles to match eggs and aliens, with the goal of hatching, breeding, and evolving them into the Supreme Alien. Players aim to build the ultimate alien hive by matching resource tiles while avoiding Naughty Bots. Power-ups can be crafted to eliminate these bots, and players are encouraged to minimize the number of moves used. As players progress, they encounter more aliens and uncover their mysteries. Magic Fruit, collected by merging seeds into saplings, is crucial for evolving Supreme Aliens, allowing players to merge similar-level aliens using only two of a kind instead of three. Evolved Supreme Aliens can be activated using gold to provide special bonuses in future games.

In App Purchase ðŸ”—

Alien Hive incorporates microtransactions, where real-world money can be exchanged for in-game gold to purchase consumable items. This aspect of the game has faced criticism, with one review suggesting that microtransactions are a necessity.

Reception ðŸ”—

Alien Hive received an average score of 70 out of 100 based on reviews aggregated by Metacritic. By 2015, the game had achieved over 3 million downloads across all platforms.

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including links to the game’s page on Appxplore’s website, the Google Play Store, a tips article on My Filing Cabinet, a review on GameZEBO, the Metacritic page, and an article on Vulcan Post.

item.title: Extraterrestrial life
item.description:
Extraterrestrial Life ðŸ”—

Extraterrestrial life, also known as alien life, refers to life that originates from another world rather than Earth. While no extraterrestrial life has been conclusively detected, the possibility ranges from simple prokaryotes to intelligent beings and civilizations. The science dedicated to studying extraterrestrial life is astrobiology.

Context ðŸ”—

This section provides a framework for understanding the topic of life in the universe. It lists various celestial bodies within and outside the Solar System that are considered potentially habitable, including Venus, Mars, Europa, Enceladus, and Titan. It also touches on the conditions necessary for life, such as the presence of liquid water and a suitable atmosphere. The section explains that the universe was initially too hot for life after the Big Bang and that the necessary elements for life, like carbon and oxygen, appeared later through stellar fusion. It also introduces the concepts of abiogenesis and panspermia as potential origins and dispersal mechanisms for life.

Likelihood of Existence ðŸ”—

This section explores the debate over whether life in the cosmos is common or rare. It presents the argument for ubiquitous extraterrestrial life, emphasizing the size and age of the universe, the ubiquity of life’s chemical elements, and the universality of physical laws. Scientists like Carl Sagan and Stephen Hawking are mentioned as proponents of this view, which is supported by the Copernican and mediocrity principles. The Rare Earth hypothesis, which posits that life on Earth is possible due to a series of unlikely factors, is also discussed. Frank Drake and his Drake equation, a probabilistic argument used to estimate the number of communicative extraterrestrial civilizations in the Milky Way, are introduced. The section concludes by mentioning the Fermi paradox, which highlights the contradiction between the high probability estimates of extraterrestrial civilizations and the lack of evidence for their existence. Dennis W. Sciama, Zhi-Wei Wang, and Samuel L. Braunstein are mentioned in relation to the Fermi paradox.

Biochemical Basis ðŸ”—

This section delves into the potential biochemical characteristics of extraterrestrial life. It discusses the basic requirements for life, such as non-equilibrium thermodynamics and a source of energy, like stars, volcanoes, or hydrothermal vents. The importance of water as a solvent is highlighted, along with the possibility of alternative solvents like ammonia or liquid hydrocarbons. The section also explores alternative chemical elements that could compose life, focusing on carbon and silicon. Norman Horowitz is mentioned for his views on carbon-based life. The section further discusses the potential for radically different biochemistries, the role of natural selection, and the likelihood of cell membranes and evolution. Simon Conway Morris is mentioned for his views on convergent evolution.

Harsh Environmental Conditions on Earth Harboring Life ðŸ”—

This section addresses the common perception that harsh conditions on other planets make them unlikely to harbor life. It presents evidence that some of the earliest and most basic forms of life on Earth originated in extreme environments, such as hydrothermal vents and acidic hot springs. These environments are characterized by intense UV radiation, extreme temperatures, and a lack of water. The section highlights the chemosynthetic processes occurring around hydrothermal vents, which allow organisms to utilize energy through reduced chemical compounds that fix carbon. It suggests that similar processes could occur on other planets with reducing atmospheres and result in the origin of extraterrestrial life.

Planetary Habitability in the Solar System ðŸ”—

This section examines the potential for life on various bodies within the Solar System. Besides Earth, Mars, Europa, and Enceladus are identified as the most likely places to find life. Venus is discussed as a terrestrial planet that may have once been similar to Earth. Mars is described as a cold desert, but with evidence of past water abundance. The gas giants are deemed unlikely to contain life, but their moons, such as Europa and Enceladus, are considered promising due to the presence of subsurface oceans. Titan, with its liquid hydrocarbon bodies, is also mentioned as a potential location for life with different biochemistry. Mary Voytek is mentioned for her views on the likelihood of finding large ecosystems.

Scientific Search ðŸ”—

This section outlines the scientific methods used to search for extraterrestrial life. Astrobiology, the science that studies life in the universe, is introduced. The section mentions the direct and indirect searches for extraterrestrial life, including the identification of thousands of exoplanets. It also mentions studies considering the possible detection of lifeforms on Venus and Mars.

Search for Basic Life ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the search for biosignatures, or evidence of life, within the Solar System and beyond. It mentions the controversial report of nanobacteria-like structures in the ALH84001 meteorite from Mars. The Viking Mars landers’ gas emission experiments are also discussed. NASA scientists’ claims of methane signatures on Mars are mentioned, along with the Mars Science Laboratory and the Curiosity rover. A catalog of microorganisms being developed at Cornell University is mentioned as a tool for searching for life on exoplanets. The discovery of organic molecules in meteorites and cosmic dust is also highlighted. The detection of glycolaldehyde, a sugar molecule, in a distant star system is mentioned as a sign that complex organic molecules may form in stellar systems prior to planet formation. The discovery of hydrogen cyanide in the plumes of Enceladus is also mentioned.

Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligences ðŸ”—

This section shifts the focus to the search for extraterrestrial intelligence. It discusses the concept of technosignatures, or effects on a planet caused by technology. The three main types of technosignatures considered are interstellar communications, effects on the atmosphere, and planetary-sized structures. Organizations like the SETI Institute are mentioned for their search for potential forms of communication. The challenges of distinguishing between natural and artificial signals are highlighted. The section also discusses potential atmospheric technosignatures, such as nitrogen dioxide, chlorofluorocarbons, and light pollution. The Kardashev scale and the possibility of detecting Dyson spheres are also mentioned.

Extrasolar Planets ðŸ”—

This section discusses the search for exoplanets that may be conducive to life. It mentions the discovery of thousands of exoplanets, ranging in size from Earth-like to gas giants. The Kepler space telescope is mentioned for its detection of thousands of candidate planets. The section highlights the estimate that at least one in five Sun-like stars have an Earth-sized planet in the habitable zone. The nearest known exoplanet, Proxima Centauri b, is mentioned. The least massive and most massive exoplanets known are also noted. The section concludes by discussing the importance of planetary habitability and the analysis of exoplanet atmospheres for signs of oxygen.

History and Cultural Impact ðŸ”—

This section explores the historical and cultural context of the search for extraterrestrial life.

Cosmic Pluralism ðŸ”—

This section traces the historical development of the idea of cosmic pluralism, the belief in numerous worlds beyond Earth. It begins with the ancient Greeks, highlighting the contrasting views of the atomists, like Epicurus, and the Aristotelians. Medieval Muslim writers like Fakhr al-Din al-Razi and Muhammad al-Baqir are mentioned for their support of cosmic pluralism. Chaucer’s poem The House of Fame is also mentioned. The section discusses the association of atomism with atheism and the varying views within the Church. The first known mention of the term ‘panspermia’ by Anaxagoras is also mentioned.

Early Modern Period ðŸ”—

This section discusses the Copernican Revolution and its impact on the notion of extraterrestrial life. Nicolaus Copernicus, Tycho Brahe, Johannes Kepler, and Galileo Galilei are mentioned for their contributions to the heliocentric model. Giordano Bruno is highlighted as an early proponent of extraterrestrial life. The section also mentions the trial of Galileo and the postulation of the theory of gravity by Isaac Newton.

19th Century ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the 19th century, highlighting the increased speculation about life on Mars following telescopic observations of apparent Martian canals. Percival Lowell is mentioned for his books proposing that the canals were the work of a long-gone civilization. William Wallace Campbell is mentioned for his spectroscopic analysis of Mars’s atmosphere. Louis Pasteur’s disproving of spontaneous generation is also discussed. JÃ¶ns Jacob Berzelius, Kelvin, Hermann von Helmholtz, and Svante Arrhenius are mentioned for their views on panspermia. The development of the science fiction genre and its influence on popular perception are also highlighted.

Recent History ðŸ”—

This section discusses the emergence of astrobiology as a science. NASA, ESA, and INAF are mentioned as organizations that study astrobiology. The section also highlights the emergence of pseudosciences, such as ufology and ancient astronauts, due to public interest in extraterrestrial life. Lewis White Beck is mentioned for his efforts to elevate the level of public discourse on extraterrestrial life. The section concludes by discussing the technological advances and increased knowledge that have fueled the interest in extraterrestrial life in the 21st century.

Government Responses ðŸ”—

This section examines the government responses to the possibility of extraterrestrial life. The 1967 Outer Space Treaty and the 1979 Moon Agreement are mentioned for defining rules of planetary protection. COSPAR is also mentioned for providing guidelines for planetary protection. The United Nations Office for Outer Space Affairs’ discussions on strategies for interacting with extraterrestrial life are highlighted. The NASA Office of Safety and Mission Assurance (OSMA) is mentioned for its mission to prevent backward contamination of Earth by extraterrestrial life. The Chinese government’s space program and its objective to search for extraterrestrial life are also noted. Dmitry Rogozin, Isaac Ben-Israel, and Haim Eshed are mentioned for their views on extraterrestrial life.

In Fiction ðŸ”—

This section explores the portrayal of extraterrestrial life in fiction.
